Study: Aerosol and Surface Stability of SARS-CoV-2 as Compared with SARS-CoV-1
Study Population: SARS-CoV-2 nCoV-WA1-2020 (MN985325.1) and SARS-CoV-1 Tor2 (AY274119.3) were the strains used.
Sample Text: Aerosols were maintained in the Goldberg drum and samples 25 were collected at 0, 30, 60, 120 and 180 minutes post-aerosolization on a 47mm gelatin filter (Sartorius).
Matches:
Virus stability on surfaces 29 Surface stability was evaluated on plastic (polypropylene, ePlastics), AISI 304 alloy stainless steel 30 (Metal Remnants), copper (99.9%) (Metal Remnants) and cardboard (local supplier) representing a variety 31 of household and hospital situations and was performed as described previously at 40% RH and 21-23°C 32 using an inoculum of 10 5 TCID50/mL (van Doremalen et al., 2013) .

Our data consist of 10 experimental conditions: 2 viruses (HCoV-19 and SARS-CoV-1) by 5 54 environmental conditions (aerosols, plastic, stainless steel copper and cardboard).

Our data consisted of 10 experimental conditions involving two viruses (SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV-1) in five environmental conditions (aerosols, plastic, stainless steel, copper, and cardboard).

The longest viability of both viruses was on stainless steel and plastic; the estimated median half-life of SARS-CoV-2 was approximately 5.6 hours on stainless steel and 6.8 hours on plastic (Figure 1C).
